channel.title: "?" and ":" Java Operators (Explanation)
channel.description:
Hey Guys, I've been around Java for awhile and never seen the ? and : operators until playing with Matrix. Would someone who knows be able to explain to me what they are and how they'd be used in an example. I've looked it up and I've been told it's got something to do with booleans and else statements but not 100% sure.
Thanks.

item.title: "?" and ":" Java Operators (Explanation)
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

To expand, the amount you can nest cleanly depends on where you’re using it.

An example of a pretty clean nested ternary statement is one I’ve seen in compareTo methods that have a simple one variable comparator (when you cant cast to integer, because if you can you can ignore the ternary all together):

public int compareTo(E other) { double difference = value - other.value; return (difference == 0 ? 0 : (difference > 0 ? 1 : -1)); }

Read full topic

item.title: "?" and ":" Java Operators (Explanation)
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

When you’re using these, don’t get carried away and start nesting a lot or using super long one-liners. They’ll make your program harder to read and maintain.

Read full topic

item.title: "?" and ":" Java Operators (Explanation)
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:8, topic:543419”][quote author=ohokay link=topic=662299.msg4426805#msg4426805 date=1401234525]

int i = 1; System.out.println("i is " + (i == 1 ? i : "not 1"));
[/quote]

That’s a very sketchy example because it implies that the tenary operator can “return” different types. The only reason it works in this example is because the + operator in this context will automatically autobox and call toString on the integer i. Why not just decide whether to print “not”?[/quote]Well the TL;DR is simple:

If anybody needs singular examples or help just post it in here I suppose.

Read full topic

item.title: "?" and ":" Java Operators (Explanation)
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

[quote=“ohokay, post:6, topic:543419”] int i = 1; System.out.println("i is " + (i == 1 ? i : "not 1"));[/quote]

That’s a very sketchy example because it implies that the tenary operator can “return” different types. The only reason it works in this example is because the + operator in this context will automatically autobox and call toString on the integer i. Why not just decide whether to print “not”?

Read full topic

item.title: "?" and ":" Java Operators (Explanation)
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

Check the links posted above.

They replace if statements.

int i = 1;

if (i == 1)
System.out.println("i is 1");
else
System.out.println("i is not 1");

int i = 1; System.out.println("i is " + (i == 1 ? i : "not 1"));

Read full topic

item.title: "?" and ":" Java Operators (Explanation)
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“Justin Bieber, post:4, topic:543419”][quote author=Snow_ link=topic=662299.msg4426680#msg4426680 date=1401180546]
They’re called ternary operators. You can say they’d ‘replace’ an if / else statement. Example:

String doesStringContainHi(String s) {
    if (s.contains("String contains hi")) {
        return true;
    } else {
        return "String doesn't contain hi";
    }
}

… could be replace by…

String doesStringContainHi(String s) {
    return (s.contains("hi") ? "String contains hi" : "String doesn't contain hi");
}

So: condition ? what if true : what if false
[/quote]
true isn’t a string buddy[/quote]

Integer IsItAString(String booleen) { return (((String) (Double)) true); }

Read full topic

item.title: "?" and ":" Java Operators (Explanation)
item.dc:creator: @Kattoor Snow_
item.description:
@Kattoor wrote:

They’re called ternary operators. You can say they’d ‘replace’ an if / else statement. Example:

String doesStringContainHi(String s) {
    if (s.contains("String contains hi")) {
        return true;
    } else {
        return "String doesn't contain hi";
    }
}

… could be replace by…

String doesStringContainHi(String s) {
    return (s.contains("hi") ? "String contains hi" : "String doesn't contain hi");
}

So: condition ? what if true : what if false
